DOCNAME: CASE OF BRITISH-AMERICAN TOBACCO COMPANY LTD v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 6-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 13;No separate issue under P1-1
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant company are a limited liability company established under the law of GPE . Their business includes the manufacture and sale of tobacco products .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant company , acting through a GPE patent agent , filed a patent application with ORG GPE ) . They claimed priority as from CARDINAL DATE on the basis of a patent application filed in GPE ( LAW ORG for the protection of industrial property , as revised ( " LAW " ) - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

The application , which concerned a cigarette , comprised CARDINAL claims ( conclusies ) . It was laid open to public inspection ( terinzagelegging ; section CARDINALC of LAW ( Rijksoctrooiwet ) - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , following a request to that effect by the applicant company ( section CARDINALI of LAW - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , ORG sent the applicant company a search report listing CARDINAL patent publications as background to the state of the article CARDINAL of these publications had been published after the date from which priority was claimed but before the filing date in the GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG Following a request ( section CARDINALJ of LAW - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) by the applicant company for a decision as to the grant of a patent , an ORG ( ORG ) consisting of CARDINAL technically qualified member of ORG stated in a letter dated DATE that in its opinion the patent claims described no patentable invention and in the same letter offered the applicant company the opportunity to refute its objections . The letter noted , inter alia , that CARDINAL of the measures described in the main claim did not appear in the corresponding application filed in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter of CARDINAL DATE the ORG agreed to publish the application for opposition purposes ( openbaarmaking ; section CARDINAL of LAW - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) provided certain changes were made . These changes included defining the scope of the protection claimed in a single patent claim , the wording of which was to conform to a suggestion made by ORG itself . However , ORG refused to recognise the priority claimed .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant company submitted CARDINAL new and independent claims , requesting recognition of the priority originally invoked only in respect of the first of these .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG gave a final decision ( eindbeschikking ) stating that the invention might equally well be described in a single claim without loss of clarity . It considered that the use of CARDINAL independent claims for the sole purpose of resolving problems relating to the recognition of the priority invoked ran counter to the requirements of fair procedure ( goede procesorde ) and could therefore not be allowed . It therefore refused to publish the application for opposition purposes .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant company lodged an appeal with ORG ( PERSON ) of ORG .

In their statement of grounds of appeal ( PERSON ) , they pointed to a number of published decisions of ORG from which it appeared , in their submission , that allowing CARDINAL independent claim in a single patent application was not unacceptable . They also expressed doubts as to how the use of CARDINAL independent claims for the sole purpose of resolving problems relating to the recognition of priority could run counter to the requirements of fair procedure . While they admitted that the invention might well be covered by a single claim , they pointed out that the scope of the protection offered by the patent would thereby be limited .

They requested ORG to overrule the decision of ORG and order the publication of the application for opposition purposes with the CARDINAL independent claims put forward by them but with a recognition of priority only in respect of the first claim . In the alternative , they requested the publication of the application for opposition purposes with the single claim proposed by ORG , the scope of which they agreed to limit further , together with recognition of the priority invoked .

CARDINAL . The Appeals Division , composed of CARDINAL technically qualified members and CARDINAL legally qualified member , held a hearing on DATE . On DATE it sent the applicant company a letter stating that for the time being it was of the opinion that neither the CARDINAL independent claims nor the single claim proposed as an alternative described any patentable invention and setting out its reasons for that view . ORG offered the applicant company the opportunity to put forward a defence against the objections thereby raised ex officio .
The applicant company replied by a letter of DATE , giving arguments to the contrary .

After ORG had made it clear that it was not convinced by these arguments , a second hearing was held on DATE which was attended by the applicant company 's GPE and NORP patent agents . The applicant company submitted fresh claims on DATE .
CARDINAL . The Appeals Division gave a final decision on CARDINAL DATE .

In the view of ORG , it did not necessarily run counter to any rule of fair procedure to use CARDINAL independent claims to circumvent problems relating to the recognition of priority . Since the applicant company 's original appeal had been limited to this issue , it was therefore declared well - founded .

Nonetheless , ORG considered that the subject - matter of the application was not patentable since it did not involve an inventive step and refused on that ground to publish the application for opposition purposes .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW DATE for the protection of industrial property , as subsequently revised on numerous occasions ( most recently in GPE on DATE , [ DATE ] CARDINAL United Nations Treaty Series , pp . CARDINAL et seq . ) , sets up a Union for the protection of industrial property . The expression " industrial property " covers patents , utility models , industrial designs , trademarks , service marks , trade names , indications of source or appellations of origin and the repression of unfair competition ( DATE ) but not copyright .
LAW is intended to prevent discrimination against non - nationals and lays down a number of very general standards as regards procedural and substantive industrial property law .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW , in so far as relevant , provides :

" A. ( CARDINAL ) Any person who has duly filed an application for a patent ... in CARDINAL of the countries of the Union , or his successor in title , shall enjoy , for the purpose of filing in the other countries , a right of priority for the periods hereinafter fixed .

B. Consequently , any subsequent filing in any of the other countries of the ORG before the expiration of the periods referred to above shall not be invalidated by reason of any acts accomplished in the interval , in particular , another filing , the publication or exploitation of the invention ... and such acts can not give rise to any third - party right or any right of personal possession ...
PERSON ( CARDINAL ) The [ period ] of priority shall be DATE for patents ...
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL , in so far as relevant , reads :

" ( CARDINAL ) Each country of the Union undertakes to establish a special industrial property service and a central office for the communication to the public of patents , utility models , industrial designs , and trademarks . ... "

CARDINAL . Patent law , both substantive and procedural , is governed by LAW of DATE , ORG ) DATE , no . CARDINAL , as subsequently amended ) . Certain procedural details are dealt with in delegated legislation made by ORG under LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG LAW provides as follows :
" A patent shall be granted , on his application , to a person who has invented a novel product or method . "
A patent must be granted unless the invention is either already known or an obvious development , given the current state of the art ( sections CARDINAL - CARDINALA ) .

To be patentable , the invention must lead to a result in the field of industry or agriculture ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . However , no patent may be granted for new varieties of plants or animals , or for essentially biological processes for producing plants or animals , except for processes involving micro - organisms ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
A patent application may only relate to a single invention or to a group of inventions based on a single inventive idea ( section CARDINALA ) .
CARDINAL . ORG A patent remains valid for DATE from the filing date of the originating application , subject to payment of an DATE fee ( sections DATE and DATE ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Subject to the provisions of LAW , a patent confers on the patentee the exclusive right , inter alia , to make , use , market , resell , hire out , deliver , import or stock the patented product or , when applicable , to apply the patented process commercially or to make , use , market , resell , hire out , deliver , import or stock the product obtained directly from the application of the patented process ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

The patentee may enforce his exclusive rights against any person ( section CARDINAL ) ; this may involve , for instance , obtaining an injunction or ( if an infringement is knowingly committed ( desbewust ) ) damages through the civil courts .

Until the application matures into a patent , the applicant whose application has been published for opposition purposes in accordance with LAW see paragraph CARDINAL below ) has an inchoate right : he may only take measures to facilitate the eventual exercise of the right he hopes to obtain . Once the patent is granted , however , the patentee may enforce his rights retrospectively with regard to actions committed between the date of publication for opposition purposes and the date on which the application matured into a patent ; such actions become retrospectively unlawful ( section CARDINAL ) . Actions prior to publication for opposition purposes remain lawful in principle , although the patentee is entitled to reasonable remuneration on a royalty basis if such actions were committed by a person who was aware that they were covered by the patent application ( section CARDINALA ) .
CARDINAL . ORG Pursuant to LAW , the right to perform acts prohibited to any person other than the patentee may be acquired from the patentee by means of a licence .

CARDINAL . ORG Both a patent and the entitlement to a patent pursuant to sections CARDINAL and following of LAW are assignable and otherwise transferable in whole or in part ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A patent may be declared null and void ( nietig ) ab initio if it does not conform to the substantive requirements laid down by LAW ( section CARDINAL ) . It may also be claimed ( opeising ) by any person who alleges that he , not the patentee , is entitled to it ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A compulsory licence under a patent may be claimed either by the holder of a patent based on a subsequent patent application if he requires it to make proper use of his own patent ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) or by ORG together with any Minister directly concerned if the interests of the ORG so require ( section CARDINALA ) .
In either case , the patentee is entitled to a reasonable remuneration .
CARDINAL . Patent applications must be filed with , and patents are granted by , ORG ( section CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG It appears from the explanatory memorandum to the bill which eventually became LAW ( Annex to Parliamentary Documents , ORG , DATE CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) that the intention was to prevent as far as possible the granting of patents " for which no good reasons exist[ed ] " . It was therefore decided to establish a system involving an examination of patent applications by a ORG agency which was " entitled , though not obliged , " to extend its examination to " all points which [ might ] be of relevance to the validity of the patent " , and in which " during the examination the opportunity [ should ] be offered for entering objections " . An expert body was created for this purpose , ORG . It was observed that only by creating such a body " [ could ] the technical experts , who [ were ] quite indispensable , obtain an independence befitting them " and " [ could ] the required guarantee be provided for the quality of the decisions which , although they [ might ] not quite be judicial decisions in the strict sense of the word , [ came ] very close to being so " .

CARDINAL . ORG The legal provisions governing the procedure before ORG are very summary , so that over DATE ORG has had to develop a number of procedural rules through its case - law to fill in gaps . For present purposes it is of interest to note that , in accordance with the aims recorded in the drafting history of LAW adverted to above , ORG does not consider itself bound by the facts as submitted to it by parties and by what is requested by applicants , but establishes the facts itself , of its own motion if need be .
The following is a summary rendering of the principal rules of patent application procedure .
CARDINAL . ORG Formal requirements relating to patent applications are to be found in LAW itself and in delegated legislation known as LAW ( Octrooireglement ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A patent application must comprise , inter alia , a general description of the invention , and the scope of the exclusive rights desired must be set forth in one or more claims appended to the description ( section CARDINALA ( CARDINAL ) ( e ) of LAW ) . The description ( which may include drawings or graphs ) must be such as to enable the person skilled in the art to understand and apply the invention , and the claims must be detailed ( section CARDINALB ( CARDINAL ) ) . The claims must enumerate separately and in detail the novel features of the invention for which exclusive rights are claimed ( Rule CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ) .
In practice the first claim generally describes the main inventive idea and other claims , dependent thereon , describe particular embodiments of the invention .
CARDINAL . ORG The priority right created by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) must be expressly invoked ( section CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG As soon as possible after DATE have passed from the date of filing , or after the date from which priority is claimed if that is earlier , the application is laid open to public inspection ( section CARDINALC ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . It then becomes part of the state of the art , to be considered in relation to subsequent applications as regards the requirement of novelty ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant , or - after the application has been laid open to public inspection - any other person , may ask ORG for a search report listing published documents which it considers relevant as descriptions of the state of the art ( section CARDINALI ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .
In practice these search reports are prepared not by ORG itself but by ORG ( pursuant to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL) ) .
Documents mentioned in the search report are usually other patent applications filed in the GPE and in other countries .
CARDINAL . ORG After the search report has been issued , the applicant or any other person may request a decision as to the grant of a patent ( section CARDINALJ ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

At this point ORG makes known any objections which it may have to the grant of a patent . In response to these the applicant may then file arguments in writing or amend the application ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

The application is then placed in the hands of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . ORG must offer the applicant the opportunity to be heard and give a decision as soon as possible thereafter ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . ORG Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW provides as follows :

" If ORG finds that no patent should be granted for all or part of the matter covered by the application , it shall give a decision not to publish the application for opposition purposes ; if it finds the opposite , it shall give a decision to publish the application [ or the part which it considers patentable ] for opposition purposes . "

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant may appeal to ORG , within DATE , against a decision not to publish the application for opposition purposes , or to publish it only in part . This is done by filing a written statement of grounds of appeal ( section CARDINALA ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

Like the proceedings before ORG , those before ORG are not adversarial . ORG must hear only the applicant , or at least offer him the opportunity to be heard . It may order a supplementary search report ( section CARDINALA ( CARDINAL ) ) . The decision of ORG is reasoned ( section CARDINALA ( CARDINAL ) ) .

CARDINAL . ORG If the application is considered patentable in whole or in part , either in the initial stage by ORG or on appeal by ORG , the application is published for opposition purposes ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Within DATE following publication of the application for opposition purposes , any person may oppose the grant of a patent ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . If no opposition is filed within that time , or if the opposition is held to be unfounded , the application becomes a patent and the exclusive rights of the patentee are established ( LAW ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Oppositions are heard by ORG which decided on the publication of the application for opposition purposes ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . If the original ORG consisted of CARDINAL member , its membership is extended to CARDINAL .

Opposition proceedings are fully adversarial : both the opposing party and the applicant are heard ( or offered the opportunity to be heard ) ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . ORG must give a reasoned decision ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .

Either party may appeal to ORG against the outcome of the opposition proceedings . Except for the fact that the appeal proceedings are also adversarial , the same rules apply to these appeals as to appeals against the decision of ORG not to publish the application for opposition purposes ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Hearings of ORG are not open to the public , nor are its decisions delivered in public .

CARDINAL . ORG Until DATE , various provisions in LAW specified the documents to which the applicant for a patent and other interested parties were to be given access ( objections ( bezwaarschriften ) , requests and statements of grounds of appeal concerning them ) . Some , but not all , of these documents were also required to be made available to the public once the patent application had been laid open to public inspection .

On DATE , a new provision ( section CARDINALA of the Patent Act ) entered into force which provides that once the patent application has been laid open to public inspection ( or published for opposition purposes , whichever is the sooner ) , any person may inspect all documents relating to the patent application which have been received by ORG or which ORG has sent to the applicant for a patent or to third parties pursuant to the provisions of LAW . As long as the patent application has not been laid open to public inspection , these documents may be inspected by third parties only with the permission of the applicant for a patent unless the third party concerned proves that the applicant for a patent has invoked the patent application against him .

CARDINAL . ORG Proceedings relating to the enforcement of a patent , for the revocation of a patent ( nietigverklaring ) and for challenging the entitlement of the patentee ( opeisen ) are brought before an ordinary civil court , ORG ( arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE ( section QUANTITY ) , whose competence in such matters is exclusive . An appeal lies to ORG ( gerechtshof ) and a further appeal on points of law ( cassatie ) to ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG Proceedings for claiming a compulsory licence are brought before ORG if the claimant is a private person ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) ; the granting of a compulsory licence in the interests of the ORG may simply be ordered by the Ministers concerned ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

The remuneration in such cases is set by ORG , if both parties agree to make a request to that effect ; if the parties can not agree either on the amount of the remuneration or to submit the matter to ORG , the patentee may file a claim before ORG ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
CARDINAL . ORG There is no statutory provision which either allows or expressly bars access to the civil courts to challenge a decision of ORG .

It appears , however , that the legislature intended the competence of ORG to be an exclusive CARDINAL . The explanatory memorandum to the bill which eventually became LAW states ( GPE to Parliamentary Documents , ORG , DATE CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) :

" The decision of ORG taken at final instance that an application [ for a patent ] should not be granted ought not to be subject to appeal . It should be assumed that when ORG , which is the expert body par excellence , considers that the law does not allow it the freedom to grant the patent applied for , that opinion is based on solid ground . In any case , the wording of a patent could hardly be left to any other body than ORG , which has the required expert knowledge . "

The competence of the administrative tribunals is expressly excluded by statute ( at the material time , section CARDINAL ( f ) of the LAW concerning administrative jurisdiction as to decisions of the administration ( FAC administratieve rechtspraak overheidsbeschikkingen - " LAW " ) ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In the GPE , the industrial property service referred to in LAW is ORG Bureau voor de Industriële Eigendom ) . ORG is part of ORG ( section CARDINAL of LAW ; LAW industriële eigendom ) ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The President of ORG is also Director of ORG ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of ORG ) . All officials and other staff - an expression which includes the members of ORG - are subordinate to him ; he may , acting on the instructions of ORG , lay down regulations for the day - to - day running of the ORG ; these are , however , subject to the Minister 's approval ( LAW ) . The Director must submit an DATE report on the ORG 's activities to the Minister for Economic Affairs ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG In taking its decisions ORG is not bound by instructions from any other administrative authority .

CARDINAL . ORG Officials and other staff of the ORG may not have any other remunerated position without the permission of the Minister for Economic Affairs . They may not be practising lawyers or patent attorneys , nor may they be involved even in an advisory capacity in an enterprise involving the filing of patent applications or the registering of trademarks , designs or semiconductor masks . They are forbidden to apply for a patent themselves ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG consists of CARDINAL ordinary members and substitute members , divided into legally qualified and technically qualified members , and of CARDINAL extraordinary members ( Rule CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The President and all members of ORG are appointed , and may be dismissed , by the ORG ( that is the Monarch together with the responsible Minister ) ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . Before taking up their duties they must take a pledge worded as follows ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW and LAW ) :

" I promise that I will diligently , meticulously and impartially discharge the duties required by the office of President [ or Vice - President , ordinary member , extraordinary member or substitute member ] of ORG , and especially that I will participate in the decisions to be taken by the ORG according to my own convictions and keep secret that which is known to me through my duties regarding patent applications in so far as these have not been laid open to public inspection or published for opposition purposes and that I will help to implement with precision the appropriate acts and ordinances ( algemene maatregelen PERSON ) and that I will not accept any promise or any gift , whether directly or indirectly , to do or omit anything in the discharge of my duties ... "
CARDINAL . ORG No member of ORG may take part in proceedings in which he has a direct or indirect interest or in which he is in any way involved ( Rule CARDINAL of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG The appointment of the President and ordinary members remains valid until their retirement .

The extraordinary members are appointed for a DATE period , which may be extended for DATE at a time ( Rule CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ) . They are recruited on the basis of expertise in a particular technical field and , in general , are university professors in CARDINAL of the technical or applied sciences .

There are no specific rules protecting the President or members of ORG against dismissal . They enjoy the same protection as other permanently appointed civil servants , who may be dismissed involuntarily only on certain limited grounds laid down by law and may contest their dismissal before ORG ( ambtenarenrechter ) .
CARDINAL . ORG There is CARDINAL case on record of dismissal of a member of ORG .

That case concerned a member of ORG who had refused an order by the President to carry out preparatory work on patent applications consisting of checking them for compliance with formal requirements . This was work normally done by lower - ranking civil servants but occasionally by members of ORG on a voluntary basis ; the assistance of the members of ORG had become necessary due to a growing backlog of work . When the member concerned refused to give his assistance voluntarily even after consultation , he was officially ordered to do so by the President . The member refused to obey and was dismissed on that ground .

He unsuccessfully contested his dismissal before both ORG and on appeal before ORG ( ORG ) . The member had not contested the order itself . For that reason the tribunals had to assume that he could only have been dismissed without justification if the order had manifestly been given without proper authority . In the particular case , the order was capable of being based on Rule CARDINAL of ORG ( Reglement Industriële Eigendom ) , a provision introduced in DATE , according to which duties incumbent on ORG but not assigned specifically to any ORG were to be carried out by the President , who was empowered to delegate them to ordinary members of ORG . ORG quoted the explanatory memorandum to the Order of DATE introducing the above LAW , from which it appeared that the competent Minister had assumed that members of ORG were subordinate to the President except in relation to decisions relating to patent applications . With regard to such decisions they could act only in accordance with their own convictions ( see the judgment of ORG of CARDINAL DATE , no . CARDINAL/B CARDINAL , unpublished ) .
CARDINAL . ORG comprises CARDINAL ORG as well as ORG , ORG and Special Divisions ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG has CARDINAL members . It is presided over ex officio by the President of ORG ; the other CARDINAL members are appointed by ORG ( Rule CARDINAL of LAW ) .
ORG decides on the composition of the other Divisions .

ORG , consisting of either CARDINAL member ( who must then be technically qualified ) or CARDINAL members ( CARDINAL or CARDINAL of whom must be legally qualified ) , decide whether a patent application may be published for opposition purposes and hear oppositions ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL above ) ( Rules CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) . The President of ORG presides over ORG ex officio but he may be replaced in his absence by a Vice - President ( Rules CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW provides as follows :
" The judiciary shall judge all disputes relating to civil rights and claims for payment . "

According to the settled case - law of ORG , this provision should be interpreted so as to encompass practically all disputes between individuals and government authorities . The civil courts are thus said to constitute a " safety net " as regards the protection of the individual against actions by the authorities . This means that although the civil courts must decide for themselves when to exercise their jurisdiction , they must declare an action inadmissible if they find that another legal remedy exists which offers sufficient procedural guarantees . On the other hand , if they find that no such remedy exists or that the existing remedy offers insufficient guarantees , they must deal with the merits of the case .

As regards actions brought by individuals against government authorities it is the established case - law of ORG since ORG PERSON v. the GPE judgment of DATE ( Series A no . CARDINAL ) that the civil courts must take into account the requirements of LAW . ( For a detailed discussion of the relevant legal developments and of the influence of the ORG judgment , see the ORG 's NORP v. the GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL . )
CARDINAL . ORG The question whether proceedings before ORG offer sufficient guarantees has only twice been submitted to the civil courts . On neither occasion was it answered conclusively .

The first time the issue was raised before a civil jurisdiction was in summary proceedings ( kort geding ) before the President of ORG of GPE ( judgment of DATE , ORG , ORG ) DATE , p. CARDINAL ) . In that case the plaintiff , against whom an injunction had been issued in earlier summary proceedings restraining it from infringing a patent owned by the defendant , asked for a declaration that this injunction applied only to the period between the issuing of the injunction and the date on which the plaintiff had requested ORG to grant a compulsory licence under the patent . The defendant pleaded that the proceedings relating to compulsory licences were not binding on it as ORG , in deciding on compulsory licences ( which in the defendant 's view amounted to the determination of civil rights and obligations as understood by DATE ( article CARDINAL ) of the Convention ) , was not an " independent and impartial tribunal " . The President of ORG declined to give a ruling on this issue . Even if its assumption were correct , the defendant could , after the grant of the compulsory licence , address itself to the civil courts , which would then decide whether the compulsory licence had been properly granted . The defendant 's objection to the arrangement for the grant of a compulsory licence could therefore in no way warrant the conclusion that such a licence should never be granted to the plaintiff , which had been the thinking underlying the defence plea .

The President of ORG commented , as an obiter dictum , that as matters stood - given the way in which the duties of ORG were stipulated by law and given the way in which the legal provisions governing proceedings relating to compulsory licences were stipulated and implemented in practice - the likelihood that in full civil proceedings ( bodemprocedure ) the GPE civil courts , or alternatively ORG , would hold ORG or the procedure relating to compulsory licences to fall foul of LAW was not sufficiently strong for him to base his decision in summary proceedings on such a hypothesis .

According to information provided by the ORG , the issue was raised a second time in DATE , when a company brought a case against the ORG before ORG of The Hague also based on a complaint about the grant of a compulsory licence under a patent which it owned . The court was asked to declare the decision of ORG unlawful , one of the reasons given being that ORG allegedly did not meet the standards of LAW . The Government has stated before this ORG that they did not raise any objection as to the admissibility of these allegations but , on the contrary , put forward defences on the merits of the question . It appears that the company decided not to pursue the case to a conclusion ; consequently , it did not result in any ruling by ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG As from DATE LAW has been replaced by an entirely new LAW , LAW of DATE , ORG ) DATE , no . CARDINAL ) . However , patent applications filed before DATE , patents granted on the basis of such applications and licences under such patents continue to be governed by LAW . LAW will ultimately be repealed .

LAW has abolished the system of substantive examination of patent applications before the grant of a patent . Following the NORP example in particular , the new system involves the registration of patents after an examination for compliance with formal requirements only . Substantive examination is left to the civil courts , upon which it is incumbent to judge whether the requirements of patentability , particularly as regards inventive step , have been complied with . Oppositions must be brought directly before the civil courts .
Under the new system ORG in its present form will ultimately cease to exist .
